before.title: Epic: CLEO Orchestration Platform - Deterministic State Machine for LLM Agent Workflows
before.description: Transform CLEO from a task management CLI into a full CI/CD-like orchestration platform for LLM agent workflows. Implements deterministic Python-based routing (not LLM interpretation), verification gates for subagent coordination via DuckDB state, and templated prompts per agent role. Covers all 5 pipeline layers: Ingestion (60-69), RCSD (30-39), Implementation (40-49), Release (50-59), and Maintenance. Key principles: No API keys, deterministic routing, state in database, templated prompts, verification gates, session isolation, async where possible, hybrid polling/events. See claudedocs/CLEO-ORCHESTRATION-PLATFORM-PROPOSAL.md for full proposal.

after.title: Epic: CLEO Orchestration Platform - Deterministic State Machine for LLM Agent Workflows

Implements deterministic Python-based routing (not LLM interpretation), verification gates for subagent coordination via DuckDB state, and templated prompts per agent role. Covers all 5 pipeline layers: Ingestion (60-69), RCSD (30-39), Implementation (40-49), Release (50-59), and Maintenance. Key principles: No API keys, deterministic routing, state in database, templated prompts, verification gates, session isolation, async where possible, hybrid polling/events. See claudedocs/CLEO-ORCHESTRATION-PLATFORM-PROPOSAL.md for full proposal.

before.title: Workflow Recipes System Integration
before.description: Research, design, and implement a comprehensive recipes system for canned workflows that enables LLM agents and users to execute complex multi-step project management workflows via single CLI commands. Integrates with CLEO position system (T805), verification gates (T1150), orchestration platform (T1062), roadmap generation (T1165), git workflow (T1114), and multi-file injection (T1384). Focus on agent-first design, security, parallel execution, and cross-epic coordination. Deliverable: claudedocs/specs/RECIPES-SYSTEM-SPEC.md for planning phase.

before.title: Add duplicate ID prevention to archive command
before.description: Modify archive.sh to check for ID conflicts BEFORE moving tasks. If task ID exists in archive: (1) Fail with clear error message, (2) Suggest repair command, (3) Never create duplicate. This is the primary prevention mechanism.

after.title: Add duplicate ID prevention to archive command
after.description: Modify archive.sh to check for ID conflicts BEFORE moving tasks. If task ID exists in archive: (1) Fail with clear error message, (2) Suggest repair command, (3) Never create duplicate. This is the primary prevention mechanism.

before.title: Implement validate --fix-duplicates for data repair
before.description: Extend validate command with --fix-duplicates flag that: (1) Detects all duplicate ID scenarios, (2) Provides interactive resolution (rename archived copy, delete duplicate, merge), (3) Updates sequence counter after repair, (4) Creates backup before any changes. Must handle: duplicate in archive, same ID in both files, sequence counter behind max ID.

after.title: Implement validate --fix-duplicates for data repair

Must handle: duplicate in archive, same ID in both files, sequence counter behind max ID.

before.title: Add ID uniqueness check to add-task.sh
before.description: Before creating any task, verify the generated ID does not exist in: (1) todo.json tasks array, (2) todo-archive.json archivedTasks array. If collision detected (should never happen with sequence system), fail with error and suggest sequence repair. Belt-and-suspenders protection.

before.title: Add sequence bootstrap to upgrade command
before.description: For projects created before v0.51.1 (no .sequence file): (1) upgrade command detects missing sequence, (2) Scans todo.json + archive for max ID, (3) Creates .sequence file with correct counter, (4) Reports action taken. Ensures all legacy projects get sequence system on upgrade.

before.title: Orchestrator Protocol Implementation
before.description: Implement a comprehensive Orchestrator Protocol for AI agent coordination. The system enforces: (1) immutable repeatable core instructions for every conversation, (2) context rot protection by keeping orchestrator high-level, (3) subagent-only execution where orchestrator NEVER does detailed work, (4) CLEO task management for tracking all work via Epics/Tasks/Subtasks with dependencies, (5) manifest-based handoff for subagent research sharing via MANIFEST.jsonl linked to tasks, (6) serial dependency execution preventing overlapping agents unless work is truly parallel, (7) autonomous operation running without user prompts after initial request.

before.title: Convert EPIC-ARCHITECT to Skill Format
before.description:
WHAT: Create skills/epic-architect/SKILL.md with proper YAML frontmatter (name, description, version, model). Extract core epic creation workflow from templates/orchestrator-protocol/subagent-prompts/EPIC-ARCHITECT.md (773 lines). Create progressive disclosure structure where SKILL.md body contains essential instructions (~1500-2000 words) and detailed content goes to references/.

WHY: Skills load ON-DEMAND via Skill tool (unlike CLAUDE.md which loads ALWAYS). Per skill-system-research, subagents do NOT inherit parent session skills - this prevents orchestrator constraints from polluting subagent contexts.

WHERE:
- Source: templates/orchestrator-protocol/subagent-prompts/EPIC-ARCHITECT.md (v2.1.0)
- Target: skills/epic-architect/SKILL.md
- Reference: skills/orchestrator/SKILL.md (use as structure template)

HOW:
1. Create skills/epic-architect/ directory
2. Create SKILL.md with frontmatter: name: epic-architect, description with trigger phrases ('create epic', 'plan epic', 'decompose into tasks', 'architect work', 'break down project', 'epic planning'), version: 2.1.0, model: sonnet
3. Extract essential content for SKILL.md body (Epic Structure, CLEO Commands, Task Decomposition, Wave Planning)
4. Keep detailed patterns (Research, Bug, Brownfield) for references/

ACCEPTANCE:
- [ ] SKILL.md exists with valid YAML frontmatter
- [ ] Description includes 5+ trigger phrases in quotes
- [ ] Body under 500 lines / 3000 words (per skill-system-research guidelines)
- [ ] Skill tool can load it successfully
- [ ] Progressive disclosure structure follows skill-system-research patterns

REFERENCES:
- skills/orchestrator/SKILL.md (v1.0.0 as template)
- claudedocs/research-outputs/2026-01-18_skill-system-research.md (structure requirements)
- templates/orchestrator-protocol/subagent-prompts/EPIC-ARCHITECT.md (source content)

before.title: Fix: Remove 2>/dev/null from context alert calls in all scripts
before.description:
IMMEDIATE FIX: Context alerts are being suppressed.

## Bug
All 4 scripts have:
```bash
check_context_alert 2>/dev/null || true
```

The 2>/dev/null suppresses stderr where alerts are written\!

## Fix
Change to:
```bash
check_context_alert || true
```

## Files to Fix
- scripts/add-task.sh (line ~1419)
- scripts/complete-task.sh
- scripts/focus.sh
- scripts/session.sh (2 places)

## Note
This is separate from the session isolation issue.
Even with isolation fixed, alerts won't show if stderr is suppressed.

after.title: Fix: Remove 2>/dev/null from context alert calls in all scripts
after.description:

before.title: EPIC: Session System Documentation & Enhancement
before.description:
EPIC: Session System Documentation & Enhancement

**RCSD Phases:**

## Phase 1: Research & Design (setup)
- T1013: Design seamless multi-agent session binding [CRITICAL BLOCKER]

## Phase 2: Core Fixes (core) 
Fix bugs blocking proper multi-session usage:
- T1012: Auto-set currentSessionId in sessions.json
- T1008: Fix session status to read from sessions.json
- T1011: Default multiSession.enabled=true in templates
- T1010: Clean up stale migrated legacy sessions

## Phase 3: Validation & UX (core)
- T1003: Improve session start UX when multiSession disabled
- T1004: Validate agent ID uniqueness
- T1005: Validate scope type enum

## Phase 4: Documentation (polish)
- T999: Rewrite docs/commands/session.md
- T1000: Document scope types and conflict detection
- T1001: Document sessions.json file structure
- T1002: Document multi-session configuration
- T1007: Update TODO_Task_Management.md
- T1009: Document CLEO_SESSION requirement

## Phase 5: Enhancements (polish)
- T1006: Auto-generate session names from scope

**Execution Model:**
- Each phase = 1 scoped session
- Tasks within phase can be parallelized by multiple agents
- Phase N+1 blocked until Phase N complete

after.title: EPIC: Session System Documentation & Enhancement

EPIC: Session System Documentation & Enhancement

**RCSD Phases:**

## Phase 2: Core Fixes (core)

- Phase N+1 blocked until Phase N complete

- Missing: mermaid support, advanced theming, CI/CD

   - Dark/light mode consistency
   - Code block syntax highlighting

   - Set up analytics dashboard
   - Add feedback widgets

- T1921: Information architecture (structure decisions)
- T1631: Mintlify research (requirements)

before.title: EPIC: RCSD Python Agent Implementation (Anthropic Agent SDK)
before.description:
Master epic for Python-based RCSD Pipeline implementation using Anthropic Agent SDK. Supersedes bash-script approach in T719 children. Implements 9-agent orchestration (1 Research + 5 Consensus Workers + 1 Synthesis + 1 Spec + 1 Decompose) as Python package under lib/rcsd/ callable from bash CLI wrappers.

## Architecture Overview
- Python package: lib/rcsd/
- Entry point: python -m rcsd.cli <stage> <args>
- Bash wrappers: scripts/{research,consensus,spec,decompose}.sh
- Output: LLM-AGENT-FIRST compliant JSON to stdout

## Agent  subagent_type Mapping
| RCSD Agent | subagent_type |
|------------|---------------|
| Research | deep-research-agent |
| Technical Validator | backend-architect |
| Design Philosophy | frontend-architect |
| Documentation | technical-writer |
| Implementation | refactoring-expert |
| Challenge/Red Team | requirements-analyst |
| Synthesis | project-supervisor-orchestrator |
| Spec Writer | technical-writer |
| Decompose | requirements-analyst |

## Exit Codes (30-39 reserved)
EXIT_RESEARCH_FAILED=30, EXIT_INSUFFICIENT_SOURCES=31, EXIT_CONSENSUS_FAILED=32, EXIT_HITL_REQUIRED=33, EXIT_SPEC_INVALID=34, EXIT_ATOMICITY_FAILED=35

## Key Specs
- RCSD-PIPELINE-SPEC.md (v1.0.0 authoritative)
- LLM-AGENT-FIRST-SPEC.md (JSON output)
- CONSENSUS-FRAMEWORK-SPEC.md (consensus protocol)
- TASK-DECOMPOSITION-SPEC.md (decompose stage)

before.title: HITL Testing: Validate automated migration system
before.description: Human-in-the-loop validation of complete automated migration system. Test scenarios: (1) PATCH change: Edit schema with maxLength increase, commit, verify hook generates complete migration automatically. (2) MINOR change: Add new optional field to schema, commit, verify hook generates template with correct TODO structure. (3) MAJOR change: Make breaking change, verify hook generates warning template. (4) Developer mode: Test CLEO_DEVELOPER_MODE=1 bypass of migrate gate. (5) Agent protection: Verify migrate command shows warning interactively, allows status/check without warning. (6) Documentation: Confirm agents cannot learn migrate command from docs. Success criteria: All scenarios work as designed, no false positives, clean user experience. BLOCKS: Epic T1463 completion.

before.title: NEXUS Agent Protocol Specification
before.description: Define the NEXUS Agent Protocol - a specification for HOW LLM agents behave and communicate. NEXUS is the agent behavior layer, while CLEO handles WHERE agents run (tmux orchestration). Separation of concerns: NEXUS = agent protocol/behavior, CLEO = infrastructure/state management. This epic covers: agent communication patterns, event-based handoffs, schema ownership model, verification gate protocols, and integration with CLEO's tmux orchestration.

Fix 80 failing tests discovered after CI infrastructure repair. Tests now run but many fail.

## GitHub Issue
https://github.com/kryptobaseddev/cleo/issues/3

## Background
CI was failing immediately due to:
1. statusline-setup.sh set -e exit (fixed v0.48.4)
2. Wrong .claude/ directory in ci.yml (fixed)
3. Incorrect bats paths in test files (fixed)

Now tests run (2269+ total) but 80 fail.

- LLM-Agent-First compliance: 17 tests
- Phase sync: 17 tests  
- Analyze size strategy: 11 tests
- Config system: 10 tests
- Hierarchy auto-complete: 7 tests
- TodoWrite sync: 7 tests
- Upgrade command: 6 tests
- Other (backup, error codes): 5 tests

v0.30.1 on Dec 23, 2025

before.title: EPIC: Fix CI Test Failures (80 tests)
before.description:
Fix 80 failing tests discovered after CI infrastructure repair. Tests now run but many fail.

## GitHub Issue
https://github.com/kryptobaseddev/cleo/issues/3

## Background
CI was failing immediately due to:
1. statusline-setup.sh set -e exit (fixed v0.48.4)
2. Wrong .claude/ directory in ci.yml (fixed)
3. Incorrect bats paths in test files (fixed)

Now tests run (2269+ total) but 80 fail.

## Categories (8 groups)
- LLM-Agent-First compliance: 17 tests
- Phase sync: 17 tests  
- Analyze size strategy: 11 tests
- Config system: 10 tests
- Hierarchy auto-complete: 7 tests
- TodoWrite sync: 7 tests
- Upgrade command: 6 tests
- Other (backup, error codes): 5 tests

## Last Successful CI
v0.30.1 on Dec 23, 2025

before.title: Enhance discover_related_tasks() with hierarchy method and boosting
before.description:
Integrate _discover_by_hierarchy() into the public discover_related_tasks() API and add hierarchical boosting to the 'auto' method.

**Changes Required**:

1. **Add 'hierarchy' case** to discover_related_tasks():
```bash
case "$method" in
    ...
    hierarchy)
        _discover_by_hierarchy "$task_id"
        ;;
```

2. **Update 'auto' method** to include hierarchy results:
```bash
auto|all)
    local labels_result description_result files_result hierarchy_result
    labels_result=$(_discover_by_labels "$task_id")
    description_result=$(_discover_by_description "$task_id")
    files_result=$(_discover_by_files "$task_id")
    hierarchy_result=$(_discover_by_hierarchy "$task_id")
    
    # Merge with hierarchy boosting applied
    echo "$labels_result" "$description_result" "$files_result" "$hierarchy_result" | \
        jq -s 'add | group_by(.taskId) | map(max_by(.score)) | sort_by(-.score)'
    ;;
```

3. **Add sibling/cousin boosting** to merged results:
- If task pair appears in hierarchy_result as sibling: add +0.2 to final score
- If task pair appears in hierarchy_result as cousin: add +0.1 to final score

**Acceptance Criteria**:
- 'hierarchy' method works standalone
- 'auto' method includes hierarchy in combined results
- Sibling boost (+0.2) applied correctly
- Cousin boost (+0.1) applied correctly
- Backward compatible (existing methods unchanged)
- Help text updated to include 'hierarchy' method

before.title: Implement _find_lca() function for lowest common ancestor
before.description:
Implement _find_lca() function to find the lowest common ancestor of two tasks in the hierarchy.

**Function Signature**:
```bash
_find_lca() {
    local task_a="$1"
    local task_b="$2"
    # Returns: LCA task ID or empty string if no common ancestor
}
```

**Algorithm**:
1. Build ancestor path for task_a (task -> parent -> grandparent -> root)
2. Build ancestor path for task_b
3. Find first common element (LCA)

**Acceptance Criteria**:
- Returns correct LCA for siblings (parent)
- Returns correct LCA for cousins (grandparent)
- Returns empty string for unrelated tasks (different root)
- Handles edge cases: same task input, null parentId
- Uses existing _graph_rag_get_task() utility

before.title: EPIC: Hierarchical Discovery System for graph-rag.sh
before.description:
Implement PageIndex-inspired hierarchical discovery features in lib/graph-rag.sh to improve task relationship discovery accuracy by 15-20%.

**Research Reference**: claudedocs/research-outputs/pageindex-rag-research.md (T2153)

**Phase 1 Scope (v0.69.0)**:
- Add _discover_by_hierarchy() function
- Add _get_hierarchical_context() for parent context propagation  
- Add _find_lca() for lowest common ancestor calculation
- Add _tree_distance() for hierarchy distance
- Enhance discover_related_tasks() with hierarchy method
- Add sibling/cousin relationship boosting

**Success Criteria**:
- +15-20% accuracy improvement on sibling task relationships
- Negligible performance impact (uses existing parentId field)
- Backward compatible with existing relates schema
- Unit tests in tests/unit/graph-rag-hierarchy.bats

**Deliverables**:
1. lib/graph-rag.sh updates (~150 lines)
2. tests/unit/graph-rag-hierarchy.bats
3. docs/commands/graph-rag.md updates

before.title: Final Consensus Synthesis
before.description:
Review ALL research across ALL sessions and produce the authoritative consensus.

## Inputs
1. All session task groups (label: consensus-source)
2. Conflict matrix (T2207)
3. All linked research files

## Process
1. Read all session research outputs
2. Compare decisions across sessions
3. For each conflict: apply structured debate
4. Document resolution rationale
5. Produce unified consensus

## Deliverables

### 1. UNIFIED-CONSENSUS.md
Final decisions on all key questions with:
- Decision statement
- Which sessions agreed
- How conflicts were resolved
- Implementation implications

### 2. Implementation Epic Spec
Ready-to-create epic with tasks following consensus decisions.
No ambiguity. No assumptions. Proven patterns only.

## Blocked By
- T2207 (Conflict Matrix) must be complete
- All consensus-source tasks must be complete

## Success Criteria
- All conflicts resolved with documented rationale
- Single authoritative decision per question
- No contradictions in final document
- Implementation epic can proceed without further debate

before.title: Session B: Multi-Agent GSD Deep Research & Consensus Validation
before.description:
Research stream using 4 parallel deep-research subagents to analyze GSD patterns.

## Session Identifier
**Session B** - Multi-agent orchestrated research (4 parallel agents)

## Research Scope
1. GSD codebase mapping (gsd-codebase-mapper agent, templates)
2. GSD atomic commit discipline (execute-plan, git-integration)
3. GSD deviation/HITL patterns (checkpoints, verification)
4. CLEO RCSD gap analysis (specs audit)

## Research Method
Spawned 4 parallel deep-research-agent subagents analyzing:
- Agent 1: Codebase Mapping Analysis
- Agent 2: Atomic Commit & Change Tracking
- Agent 3: Deviation Rules & HITL
- Agent 4: CLEO RCSD Gap Analysis

## Key Decisions (5 Questions)
1. Codebase Map: Single JSON -  AGREES with Session A
2. Staleness: Warn-only default -  AGREES with Session A
3. Task Creation: Auto w/ dry-run -  AGREES with Session A
4. Changesets: Per-task w/ commits[] -  AGREES with Session A
5. Phase UX: Implicit states -  AGREES with Session A

## Conflicts
**NONE** - All 5 decisions align with Session A.

## Value Added
- Line-number citations from GSD source files
- 4-rule deviation model  CLEO consensus mapping
- Checkpoint distribution (90/9/1)
- Dynamic auth gate pattern
- GSD Golden Rule documentation

before.title: Delete unused injection_extract_version function
before.description:
**Problem**: `injection_extract_version()` in lib/injection-config.sh (lines 51-64) is dead code. It was designed for legacy versioned markers (`CLEO:START v1.0.0`) but:
1. New markers don't have versions
2. No code calls this function (verified via grep)
3. Function comment says 'returns empty for new versionless markers (which is expected)'

**Location**: lib/injection-config.sh lines 51-64

**Fix**: Delete the entire `injection_extract_version()` function.

**Dependency**: Should be done AFTER T2225 and T2226 (to confirm version field removal is complete)

**Acceptance**:
- [ ] Function removed from lib/injection-config.sh
- [ ] No grep hits for injection_extract_version in codebase
- [ ] All tests still pass
- [ ] Documentation updated if function was documented

1. New markers don't have versions
2. No code calls this function (verified via grep)
3. Function comment says 'returns empty for new versionless markers (which is expected)'

**Location**: lib/injection-config.sh lines 51-64

**Fix**: Delete the entire `injection_extract_version()` function.

before.title: Sync features from config.json during upgrade
before.description:
**Problem**: DRY violation - init.sh (lines 946-954) and upgrade.sh (lines 446-451) hardcode identical feature defaults:
```json
"features": {
    "multiSession": false,
    "verification": false,
    "contextAlerts": false
}
```
These should read actual values from config.json instead of hardcoding.

**Locations**:
- scripts/init.sh lines 946-954
- scripts/upgrade.sh lines 446-451

**Fix**: Read feature settings from config.json:
```bash
local multi_session=$(jq -r '.multiSession.enabled // false' "$config_file")
local verification=$(jq -r '.verification.enabled // false' "$config_file")
local context_alerts=$(jq -r '.contextAlerts.enabled // false' "$config_file")
```

Then use these values in the jq expression.

**Dependency**: Requires T2228 (schema update) to be complete first

**Acceptance**:
- [ ] init.sh reads features from config.json
- [ ] upgrade.sh reads features from config.json
- [ ] New projects get default values (no config.json yet)
- [ ] Existing projects reflect actual config settings
- [ ] DRY principle satisfied - no duplicate hardcoded values

before.title: Add feature consistency health check to doctor
before.description:
**Problem**: Doctor doesn't validate that features in project-info.json match config.json settings. This means stale project-info.json files can have incorrect feature flags.

**Current behavior**: Doctor checks validation, schema versions, injection status - but NOT feature consistency.

**Fix**: Add new health check to doctor.sh:
1. Read features from project-info.json
2. Read actual settings from config.json
3. Compare and warn if mismatched
4. Issue code: FEATURE_MISMATCH
5. Suggested fix: `cleo upgrade`

**Example output**:
```
 Feature mismatch: multiSession is false in project-info but enabled in config
  Fix: Run 'cleo upgrade' to sync feature status
```

**Dependency**: Requires T2228 (schema) and T2229 (sync logic) to be complete

**Acceptance**:
- [ ] Doctor detects feature mismatches
- [ ] Warning shown with specific mismatched features
- [ ] Fix command suggested
- [ ] No false positives (handles missing config gracefully)
- [ ] Check is skipped for new projects without config.json

before.title: Final Consensus Synthesis
before.description:
Review ALL research across ALL sessions and produce the authoritative consensus.

## Inputs
1. All session task groups (label: consensus-source)
2. Conflict matrix (T2207)
3. All linked research files

## Process
1. Read all session research outputs
2. Compare decisions across sessions
3. For each conflict: apply structured debate
4. Document resolution rationale
5. Produce unified consensus

## Deliverables

### 1. UNIFIED-CONSENSUS.md
Final decisions on all key questions with:
- Decision statement
- Which sessions agreed
- How conflicts were resolved
- Implementation implications

### 2. Implementation Epic Spec
Ready-to-create epic with tasks following consensus decisions.
No ambiguity. No assumptions. Proven patterns only.

## Blocked By
- T2207 (Conflict Matrix) must be complete
- All consensus-source tasks must be complete

## Success Criteria
- All conflicts resolved with documented rationale
- Single authoritative decision per question
- No contradictions in final document
- Implementation epic can proceed without further debate

before.title: RCSD Integration Research Consolidation
before.description:
Meta-orchestration epic to consolidate all parallel RCSD/GSD research streams into a single validated consensus.

## Problem
Multiple agent sessions are conducting parallel research on:
- GSD codebase mapping patterns
- RCSD pipeline implementation
- Atomic commit discipline integration
- Phase-flow UX adaptation
- Consensus mechanisms

Different sessions may have divergent conclusions. This epic establishes a structured process to:
1. Collect all research under tagged task groups
2. Cross-validate findings
3. Resolve conflicts through structured debate
4. Produce a single authoritative consensus

## Protocol
Each contributing agent session MUST:
1. Create a child task group under this epic with session identifier
2. Link ALL their research outputs to their task group
3. Document key decisions and rationale
4. Explicitly flag conflicts with other sessions' findings

## Deliverables
- Tagged research from all sessions
- Cross-session conflict matrix
- Final unified consensus document
- Implementation roadmap with no ambiguity

## Success Criteria
- 100% research linked to task groups
- All conflicts identified and resolved
- Single consensus document approved
- Implementation epic ready for execution

before.title: Decision: Changeset Storage Model
before.description:
Decide where changeset data is stored.

## Options Identified
A. **Embedded in task** - Store in task.changeset field in todo.json
   - Pros: Simple, single file, CLEO-native
   - Cons: Bloats todo.json, limited metadata

B. **Separate files** - Store in .cleo/changes/T001.json per task
   - Pros: GSD pattern, rich metadata, reviewable, git-trackable
   - Cons: More files, more complexity

C. **@changesets/cli compatible** - Store in .changeset/*.md
   - Pros: Industry standard, external tooling support
   - Cons: Node dependency, different paradigm

before.title: Decision: Changeset Capture Timing
before.description:
Decide WHEN changeset data is captured.

## Options Identified
A. **On ct complete** - Automatic capture when task is marked done
   - Pros: Zero friction, guaranteed capture
   - Cons: May miss multi-commit work, timing issues

B. **Manual ct changeset** - Explicit command to capture changes
   - Pros: More control, developer decides what to include
   - Cons: More friction, may be forgotten

C. **Per-commit hook** - Git hook captures on each commit
   - Pros: Captures ALL commits, complete audit trail
   - Cons: Complex setup, may capture too much noise

D. **Hybrid** - Auto on complete + manual override
   - Pros: Best of both worlds
   - Cons: More complex implementation

## Session Contributions

before.title: Decision: Git Integration Depth
before.description:
Decide HOW DEEP git integration goes for changesets.

## Options Identified
A. **Shallow** - Just commit hash
   - Captured: hash only
   - Pros: Minimal, fast
   - Cons: Need git log to see details

B. **Medium** - Hash + file list
   - Captured: hash, list of files changed
   - Pros: Know what was touched without git
   - Cons: More storage, but manageable

C. **Deep** - Hash + files + diff summary
   - Captured: hash, files, insertions/deletions, maybe commit message
   - Pros: Complete audit trail, self-contained
   - Cons: Storage bloat, complexity

## TDD Consideration
With RED/GREEN/REFACTOR creating 2-3 commits per task, deeper capture means more data.

before.title: Decision: Commit Message Format Standard
before.description:
Decide the standard commit message format for CLEO workflows.

## Options Identified
A. **Conventional Commits** - {type}({scope}): {description}
   - Example: feat(auth): add JWT refresh token support
   - Pros: Industry standard, tooling support, semantic-release compatible
   - Cons: No task linkage built-in

B. **Phase-Plan Format** - {type}({phase}-{plan}): {description}
   - Example: feat(core-T1234): add JWT refresh token support
   - Pros: Explicit phase context, task linkage
   - Cons: Non-standard, no external tooling

C. **Hybrid** - Conventional + Task footer
   - Example: feat(auth): add JWT refresh token\n\nTask: T1234
   - Pros: Best of both, tooling compatible, task linked
   - Cons: Requires discipline to add footer

## Enforcement
Should CLEO validate commit messages? Hook? Advisory?

before.title: Decision: Release Automation Tooling
before.description:
Decide what tooling handles release automation.

## Options Identified
A. **release-please** (Google)
   - Reads conventional commits, creates Release PRs
   - Pros: Automated, creates PRs (branch protection friendly)
   - Cons: Another GitHub Action, opinionated changelog format

B. **@changesets/cli**
   - Developer creates .changeset files per PR
   - Pros: Explicit change tracking, great for monorepos
   - Cons: Node dependency, more workflow steps

C. **semantic-release**
   - Fully automated from commits
   - Pros: Zero manual intervention
   - Cons: Very opinionated, Node dependency

D. **Custom CLEO** (ct release commands)
   - Native CLEO commands: ct release plan/ship
   - Pros: CLEO-native, dogfooding, works for users too
   - Cons: Development effort, reinventing wheel?

E. **Hybrid** - CLEO + external tool
   - CLEO tracks changesets, external tool handles version/tag
   - Pros: Best of both
   - Cons: More moving parts

## For CLEO Dev vs For CLEO Users
Different answers may apply to CLEO development vs what CLEO offers its users.

before.title: Decision: RCSD  Implementation Handoff
before.description:
Define how RCSD Protocol outputs feed into Implementation Protocol.

## Handoff Points
1. Research findings  Task context
2. Consensus decisions  Implementation constraints
3. Specifications  Acceptance criteria
4. Decomposition  Epic/Task structure

## Questions to Resolve
- What artifacts does RCSD produce?
- How are they linked to implementation tasks?
- Is there a 'gate' between RCSD and Implementation?
- Can implementation start before full consensus?

## Phase-Flow UX Concepts
- 'Gray area' analysis before planning

before.title: Create CONTRIBUTION-PROTOCOL.template.md
before.description:
Create parameterized protocol template with token placeholders.

## Depends On
T2268 (pattern analysis) - need parameterization map

## Template Structure
1. **Header block** - `{{EPIC_ID}}`, `{{EPIC_TITLE}}`, `{{DATE}}`
2. **Baseline reference** - `{{BASELINE_SESSION_ID}}`, `{{BASELINE_DECISIONS}}`
3. **Decision questions** - `{{DECISION_QUESTIONS}}` (array injection)
4. **RFC 2119 block** - Numbered requirements (invariant)
5. **Validation checklist** - Agent self-check (invariant)

## Tokens Required
| Token | Type | Example |
|-------|------|---------|
| `{{EPIC_ID}}` | string | T2204 |
| `{{BASELINE_SESSION_ID}}` | string | T2205 |
| `{{DECISION_QUESTIONS}}` | array | [{id, question, baseline}] |

## Deliverable
`templates/CONTRIBUTION-PROTOCOL.template.md`

## Constraint
Total invariant content <500 tokens for low context impact

before.title: Design subagent injection block
before.description:
Create minimal injection block for subagent prompts.

## Depends On
T2268 (pattern analysis) - need RFC 2119 requirements list

## Constraint
**<200 tokens** - Must be injectable without significant context cost

## Content
1. RFC 2119 requirements (numbered, terse)
2. Output format requirement
3. Conflict flagging requirement
4. Completion criteria
5. Pointer to full protocol (not inline)

## Format
```markdown
## CONTRIBUTION PROTOCOL (RFC 2119)
[Numbered requirements here]
Full protocol: {{PROTOCOL_PATH}}
```

## Deliverable
`templates/CONTRIBUTION-INJECTION.md` (~150-200 tokens)

## Validation
- Token count verified
- All critical requirements present
- No redundancy with full protocol

before.title: Implement lib/contribution-protocol.sh
before.description:
Implement shell library for protocol instantiation and validation.

## Depends On
- T2269 (schema) - for validation
- T2270 (template) - for instantiation
- T2271 (injection) - for injection generation

## Functions

### Instantiation
```bash
contribution_protocol_instantiate()
  # Input: epic_id, baseline_session, questions_json
  # Output: Instantiated protocol markdown
```

### Validation
```bash
contribution_validate_task()
  # Input: task_id
  # Output: JSON validation result
  # Validates against contribution.schema.json
```

### Injection
```bash
contribution_get_injection()
  # Input: epic_id, protocol_path
  # Output: Injection block (<200 tokens)
```

## Deliverable
`lib/contribution-protocol.sh`

## Integration
- Uses existing token-inject.sh patterns
- Uses existing validation.sh patterns
- JSON output for all functions

before.title: Session C: Orchestrator Core Philosophy & Anti-Hallucination Protocol
before.description:
Research stream focused on orchestrator core philosophy, anti-hallucination patterns, and provenance enforcement.

## Session Identifier
**Session C** - HITL-driven brainstorm + 3 parallel subagent analysis

## Research Scope
1. LLM instruction stickiness and what makes instructions 'stick'
2. Anti-hallucination patterns and constraint optimization
3. Provenance enforcement mechanisms (commit, JSDoc, completion gates)
4. Deterministic agent contract specification

## Research Method
- Interactive HITL brainstorm session
- 3 parallel subagents: deep-research-agent, system-architect, requirements-analyst
- RFC 2119 specification development

## Key Decisions (Aligned with Sessions A & B + NEW)
1. **Core Mantra**: 'Scope down. Trace to Epic. No orphaned work.'
2. **Maximum Scope Limits**: 3 files/agent, 0 architectural decisions/agent
3. **JSDoc Standard**: @task (MUST), @epic (SHOULD), @why/@what (MUST)
4. **Enforcement Layers**: L1-Spawn (hard), L2-Commit (hard+audit), L3-Complete (soft), L4-JSDoc (progressive)
5. **Brownfield Strategy**: Zone-based (Green/Yellow/Red) with forward-only enforcement

## New Findings (Beyond Sessions A/B)
- LLM instruction stickiness research: parallelism, rhythm, concrete anchors
- Determinism equation: Determinism = (Atomicity  Provenance) / (Scope  Ambiguity)
- 4-layer enforcement architecture with escape hatches
- Agent contract schema with exit codes 60-69

## Conflicts with Sessions A/B
**NONE** - Builds upon and extends A/B findings. Adds enforcement specifics.

## Research Outputs
- 2026-01-25_llm-instruction-stickiness.md (from deep-research-agent)
- 2026-01-25_provenance-enforcement-design.md (from system-architect)
- 2026-01-25_deterministic-agent-contract.md (from requirements-analyst)
- docs/specs/AGENT-CONTRACT-SPEC.md (created by requirements-analyst)

before.title: Decision: Changeset Storage Model
before.description:
Decide where changeset data is stored.

## Options Identified
A. **Embedded in task** - Store in task.changeset field in todo.json
   - Pros: Simple, single file, CLEO-native
   - Cons: Bloats todo.json, limited metadata

B. **Separate files** - Store in .cleo/changes/T001.json per task
   - Pros: GSD pattern, rich metadata, reviewable, git-trackable
   - Cons: More files, more complexity

C. **@changesets/cli compatible** - Store in .changeset/*.md
   - Pros: Industry standard, external tooling support
   - Cons: Node dependency, different paradigm

before.title: Decision: Changeset Capture Timing
before.description:
Decide WHEN changeset data is captured.

## Options Identified
A. **On ct complete** - Automatic capture when task is marked done
   - Pros: Zero friction, guaranteed capture
   - Cons: May miss multi-commit work, timing issues

B. **Manual ct changeset** - Explicit command to capture changes
   - Pros: More control, developer decides what to include
   - Cons: More friction, may be forgotten

C. **Per-commit hook** - Git hook captures on each commit
   - Pros: Captures ALL commits, complete audit trail
   - Cons: Complex setup, may capture too much noise

D. **Hybrid** - Auto on complete + manual override
   - Pros: Best of both worlds
   - Cons: More complex implementation

before.title: Decision: Git Integration Depth
before.description:
Decide HOW DEEP git integration goes for changesets.

## Options Identified
A. **Shallow** - Just commit hash
   - Captured: hash only
   - Pros: Minimal, fast
   - Cons: Need git log to see details

B. **Medium** - Hash + file list
   - Captured: hash, list of files changed
   - Pros: Know what was touched without git
   - Cons: More storage, but manageable

C. **Deep** - Hash + files + diff summary
   - Captured: hash, files, insertions/deletions, maybe commit message
   - Pros: Complete audit trail, self-contained
   - Cons: Storage bloat, complexity

## TDD Consideration
With RED/GREEN/REFACTOR creating 2-3 commits per task, deeper capture means more data.

before.title: Decision: Commit Message Format Standard
before.description:
Decide the standard commit message format for CLEO workflows.

## Options Identified
A. **Conventional Commits** - {type}({scope}): {description}
   - Example: feat(auth): add JWT refresh token support
   - Pros: Industry standard, tooling support, semantic-release compatible
   - Cons: No task linkage built-in

B. **Phase-Plan Format** - {type}({phase}-{plan}): {description}
   - Example: feat(core-T1234): add JWT refresh token support
   - Pros: Explicit phase context, task linkage
   - Cons: Non-standard, no external tooling

C. **Hybrid** - Conventional + Task footer
   - Example: feat(auth): add JWT refresh token\n\nTask: T1234
   - Pros: Best of both, tooling compatible, task linked
   - Cons: Requires discipline to add footer

## Enforcement
Should CLEO validate commit messages? Hook? Advisory?

before.title: Decision: Release Automation Tooling
before.description:
Decide what tooling handles release automation.

## Options Identified
A. **release-please** (Google)
   - Reads conventional commits, creates Release PRs
   - Pros: Automated, creates PRs (branch protection friendly)
   - Cons: Another GitHub Action, opinionated changelog format

B. **@changesets/cli**
   - Developer creates .changeset files per PR
   - Pros: Explicit change tracking, great for monorepos
   - Cons: Node dependency, more workflow steps

C. **semantic-release**
   - Fully automated from commits
   - Pros: Zero manual intervention
   - Cons: Very opinionated, Node dependency

D. **Custom CLEO** (ct release commands)
   - Native CLEO commands: ct release plan/ship
   - Pros: CLEO-native, dogfooding, works for users too
   - Cons: Development effort, reinventing wheel?

E. **Hybrid** - CLEO + external tool
   - CLEO tracks changesets, external tool handles version/tag
   - Pros: Best of both
   - Cons: More moving parts

## For CLEO Dev vs For CLEO Users
Different answers may apply to CLEO development vs what CLEO offers its users.

before.title: Agent Contribution Protocol
before.description:
Core protocol for contributing agents. See full instructions in claudedocs/research-outputs/AGENT-CONTRIBUTION-PROTOCOL.md

## Quick Reference

1. Create child task: `cleo add "Session X: [Focus]" --parent T2204 --labels session-x,consensus-source`
2. List ALL research files in description
3. Add file paths in notes for auto-linking
4. Document decisions on 5 key questions
5. Flag conflicts with Session A (T2205)
6. Mark complete when done

## Key Questions to Answer
1. Codebase map: single vs split?
2. Staleness: warn vs block vs auto-refresh?
3. Task creation: auto vs approval-required?
4. Changesets: per-task vs per-commit?
5. Phase UX: explicit commands vs implicit states?

## Critical Rules
- MUST use label `consensus-source`
- MUST flag conflicts explicitly
- MUST NOT make code changes

after.title: Agent Contribution Protocol
after.description:
Core protocol for contributing agents. See full instructions in claudedocs/research-outputs/AGENT-CONTRIBUTION-PROTOCOL.md

## Protocol Status
- **Version**: 1.0.0 (migrated to protocolized infrastructure)
- **Generated via**: `lib/contribution-protocol.sh`
- **Baseline Session**: Session A (T2205)
- **Marker Label**: consensus-source

## Quick Reference

1. Create child task: `cleo add "Session X: [Focus]" --parent T2204 --labels session-x,consensus-source`
2. List ALL research files in description
3. Add file paths in notes for auto-linking
4. Document decisions on 5 key questions (Q1-Q5)
5. Flag conflicts with Session A (T2205)
6. Mark complete when done

## Key Questions to Answer
- Q1: Codebase map: single vs split?
- Q2: Staleness: warn vs block vs auto-refresh?
- Q3: Task creation: auto vs approval-required?
- Q4: Changesets: per-task vs per-commit?
- Q5: Phase UX: explicit commands vs implicit states?

## Critical Rules (RFC 2119)
- **MUST** use label `consensus-source`
- **MUST** flag conflicts with Session A explicitly
- **MUST NOT** make code changes - planning only

## Library Functions
- `contribution_protocol_instantiate()` - Generate protocol from template
- `contribution_validate_task()` - Validate task compliance
- `contribution_get_injection()` - Get subagent injection block

before.title: Decision: Changeset Storage Model
before.description:
Decide where changeset data is stored.

## Options Identified
A. **Embedded in task** - Store in task.changeset field in todo.json
   - Pros: Simple, single file, CLEO-native
   - Cons: Bloats todo.json, limited metadata

B. **Separate files** - Store in .cleo/changes/T001.json per task
   - Pros: GSD pattern, rich metadata, reviewable, git-trackable
   - Cons: More files, more complexity

C. **@changesets/cli compatible** - Store in .changeset/*.md
   - Pros: Industry standard, external tooling support
   - Cons: Node dependency, different paradigm

before.title: Decision: Changeset Capture Timing
before.description:
Decide WHEN changeset data is captured.

## Options Identified
A. **On ct complete** - Automatic capture when task is marked done
   - Pros: Zero friction, guaranteed capture
   - Cons: May miss multi-commit work, timing issues

B. **Manual ct changeset** - Explicit command to capture changes
   - Pros: More control, developer decides what to include
   - Cons: More friction, may be forgotten

C. **Per-commit hook** - Git hook captures on each commit
   - Pros: Captures ALL commits, complete audit trail
   - Cons: Complex setup, may capture too much noise

D. **Hybrid** - Auto on complete + manual override
   - Pros: Best of both worlds
   - Cons: More complex implementation

## Session Contributions

before.title: Decision: Git Integration Depth
before.description:
Decide HOW DEEP git integration goes for changesets.

## Options Identified
A. **Shallow** - Just commit hash
   - Captured: hash only
   - Pros: Minimal, fast
   - Cons: Need git log to see details

B. **Medium** - Hash + file list
   - Captured: hash, list of files changed
   - Pros: Know what was touched without git
   - Cons: More storage, but manageable

C. **Deep** - Hash + files + diff summary
   - Captured: hash, files, insertions/deletions, maybe commit message
   - Pros: Complete audit trail, self-contained
   - Cons: Storage bloat, complexity

## TDD Consideration
With RED/GREEN/REFACTOR creating 2-3 commits per task, deeper capture means more data.

before.title: Decision: Commit Message Format Standard
before.description:
Decide the standard commit message format for CLEO workflows.

## Options Identified
A. **Conventional Commits** - {type}({scope}): {description}
   - Example: feat(auth): add JWT refresh token support
   - Pros: Industry standard, tooling support, semantic-release compatible
   - Cons: No task linkage built-in

B. **Phase-Plan Format** - {type}({phase}-{plan}): {description}
   - Example: feat(core-T1234): add JWT refresh token support
   - Pros: Explicit phase context, task linkage
   - Cons: Non-standard, no external tooling

C. **Hybrid** - Conventional + Task footer
   - Example: feat(auth): add JWT refresh token\n\nTask: T1234
   - Pros: Best of both, tooling compatible, task linked
   - Cons: Requires discipline to add footer

## Enforcement
Should CLEO validate commit messages? Hook? Advisory?

## Session Contributions

before.title: Decision: Release Automation Tooling
before.description:
Decide what tooling handles release automation.

## Options Identified
A. **release-please** (Google)
   - Reads conventional commits, creates Release PRs
   - Pros: Automated, creates PRs (branch protection friendly)
   - Cons: Another GitHub Action, opinionated changelog format

B. **@changesets/cli**
   - Developer creates .changeset files per PR
   - Pros: Explicit change tracking, great for monorepos
   - Cons: Node dependency, more workflow steps

C. **semantic-release**
   - Fully automated from commits
   - Pros: Zero manual intervention
   - Cons: Very opinionated, Node dependency

D. **Custom CLEO** (ct release commands)
   - Native CLEO commands: ct release plan/ship
   - Pros: CLEO-native, dogfooding, works for users too
   - Cons: Development effort, reinventing wheel?

E. **Hybrid** - CLEO + external tool
   - CLEO tracks changesets, external tool handles version/tag
   - Pros: Best of both
   - Cons: More moving parts

## For CLEO Dev vs For CLEO Users
Different answers may apply to CLEO development vs what CLEO offers its users.

before.title: Final Consensus Synthesis
before.description:
Review ALL research across ALL sessions and produce the authoritative consensus.

## Inputs
1. All session task groups (label: consensus-source)
2. Conflict matrix (T2207)
3. All linked research files

## Process
1. Read all session research outputs
2. Compare decisions across sessions
3. For each conflict: apply structured debate
4. Document resolution rationale
5. Produce unified consensus

## Deliverables

### 1. UNIFIED-CONSENSUS.md
Final decisions on all key questions with:
- Decision statement
- Which sessions agreed
- How conflicts were resolved
- Implementation implications

### 2. Implementation Epic Spec
Ready-to-create epic with tasks following consensus decisions.
No ambiguity. No assumptions. Proven patterns only.

## Blocked By
- T2207 (Conflict Matrix) must be complete
- All consensus-source tasks must be complete

## Success Criteria
- All conflicts resolved with documented rationale
- Single authoritative decision per question
- No contradictions in final document
- Implementation epic can proceed without further debate

before.title: EPIC: Contribution Protocol System v2 - JSON-First Multi-Agent Consensus
before.description:
Legitimize and harden the Contribution Protocol for structured multi-agent consensus workflows.

## Problem
Current contribution protocol (T2262) uses markdown templates. Markdown is NOT optimized for:
- Machine validation of contributions
- Structured conflict detection
- Multi-agent consensus aggregation
- Programmatic synthesis

## Solution
JSON/JSONL-first contribution system with:
1. Structured contribution format (JSON)
2. Machine-parseable conflict detection
3. Automated consensus aggregation
4. Skill-based workflow integration

## Builds On
- T2262: Contribution Protocol Infrastructure (DONE) - schema, template, lib
- T2204: RCSD Integration Research Consolidation - first consumer

## Deliverables
1. JSON contribution format spec
2. JSONL manifest for contribution tracking
3. Contribution Protocol Skill (/contribution)
4. Usage guide (docs/guides/CONTRIBUTION-PROTOCOL-GUIDE.md)
5. Conflict detection automation
6. Consensus aggregation tooling
7. RCSD pipeline integration updates

## Success Criteria
- Contributions are 100% JSON (no markdown decisions)
- Conflicts machine-detectable
- Consensus can be computed programmatically
- Skill provides guided workflow for agents

before.title: BUG: Active sessions never auto-end/archive - causes unbounded accumulation
before.description:
## Problem
15+ active sessions accumulating, many from weeks ago. The `session_auto_archive()` function in lib/sessions.sh ONLY targets 'ended' or 'suspended' sessions - it NEVER processes 'active' sessions.

## Root Cause
- `sessionTimeoutHours` config (24h) only generates warnings during `session end` - doesn't auto-transition
- `session gc` runs auto_archive but skips active sessions entirely
- No detection of stale active sessions (lastActivity > X days)

## Evidence
- session_20251230_232225_71660c: lastActivity 2025-12-31 (26 days stale)
- session_20260103_155207_c21933: lastActivity 2026-01-03 (23 days stale)
- 15 active sessions total, should be 1-3 max

## Solution Options
1. Add `retention.autoEndActiveAfterDays` config (default: 7)
2. `session gc --include-active` to end stale active sessions
3. Add `session_auto_end_stale()` function mirroring `session_auto_archive()`
4. Warning during `session start` when stale active sessions exist

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Active sessions older than threshold auto-transitioned to 'ended'
- [ ] `session gc` has option to handle stale active sessions
- [ ] `session doctor` warns about stale active sessions
- [ ] Config `retention.autoEndActiveAfterDays` available

before.title: BUG: session list fails with 'Argument list too long' when sessions.json > ~130KB
before.description:
## Problem
session list command fails with 'Argument list too long' when sessions.json grows large.

## Root Cause
scripts/session.sh line 1774 uses:
```bash
--argjson sessions "$sessions"
```

When sessions array is large (332KB in our case with 221 sessions), this exceeds shell argument limit.

## Evidence
```
/home/.../.cleo/scripts/session.sh: line 1771: /usr/bin/jq: Argument list too long
```

## Solution
Use stdin for large JSON instead of --argjson:
```bash
echo "$sessions" | jq -n --slurpfile sessions /dev/stdin ...
```

Or use process substitution:
```bash
jq -n --slurpfile sessions <(echo "$sessions") ...
```

## Affected Commands
- session list
- session doctor  
- Any command reading sessions array

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] session list works with 200+ sessions
- [ ] No argument list too long errors
- [ ] Performance acceptable with large session counts

before.title: BUG: session end command cannot accept session ID as argument
before.description:
## Problem
In multi-session mode, cannot end a specific session by providing ID as argument.

## Evidence
```bash
cleo session end session_20251231_140205_e07e64 --note 'Test'
# Fails - session ID is ignored

# Only works with env var:
CLEO_SESSION=session_xxx cleo session end --note 'Test'
```

## Root Cause
scripts/session.sh cmd_end() lines 858-862:
```bash
while [[ $# -gt 0 ]]; do
  case $1 in
    --note) note="$2"; shift 2 ;;
    *) shift ;;  # <-- Ignores positional args!
  esac
done
```

## Solution
Add positional session ID parsing like other session subcommands:
```bash
case $1 in
  --note) note="$2"; shift 2 ;;
  session_*) session_id="$1"; shift ;;  # Accept session ID
  *) shift ;;
esac
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- `cleo session end SESSION_ID --note 'text'` works
- `cleo session end --note 'text'` uses current session (backward compat)
- Error message when no session resolvable

before.title: EPIC: Hierarchical Discovery System for graph-rag.sh
before.description:
Implement PageIndex-inspired hierarchical discovery features in lib/graph-rag.sh to improve task relationship discovery accuracy by 15-20%.

**Research Reference**: claudedocs/research-outputs/pageindex-rag-research.md (T2153)

**Phase 1 Scope (v0.69.0)**:
- Add _discover_by_hierarchy() function
- Add _get_hierarchical_context() for parent context propagation  
- Add _find_lca() for lowest common ancestor calculation
- Add _tree_distance() for hierarchy distance
- Enhance discover_related_tasks() with hierarchy method
- Add sibling/cousin relationship boosting

**Success Criteria**:
- +15-20% accuracy improvement on sibling task relationships
- Negligible performance impact (uses existing parentId field)
- Backward compatible with existing relates schema
- Unit tests in tests/unit/graph-rag-hierarchy.bats

**Deliverables**:
1. lib/graph-rag.sh updates (~150 lines)
2. tests/unit/graph-rag-hierarchy.bats
3. docs/commands/graph-rag.md updates

- T1165: Roadmap Generation - backlog

after.description: REFRAMED: Complete minimal .claude-plugin/ for Claude Code hooks ONLY. Scope: (1) Complete plugin.json with proper schema, (2) Create hooks/ directory structure, (3) NO agents/, NO commands/ - these are handled by injection+skills. Plugin is OPTIONAL and Claude Code-specific. Injection system remains primary for multi-agent support.

before.title: Implement hooks configuration and scripts
before.description: Create hooks/hooks.json with SessionStart, Stop, UserPromptSubmit hooks. Create hooks/scripts/: session-start.sh (auto-start cleo session), check-focus.sh (remind about focus), session-end.sh (optional cleanup). Use CLAUDE_PLUGIN_ROOT for paths.

after.title: Implement hooks configuration and scripts
after.description: REFRAMED (Minimal): Create hooks/hooks.json with SessionStart hook ONLY for cleo session auto-binding. Single hook: session-start.sh binds CLEO_SESSION env var when Claude Code starts. NO Stop/UserPromptSubmit hooks - keep scope minimal. Plugin is optional supplement to injection system.

before.title: Update install.sh with plugin symlink support
before.description: Add install_plugin() function to install.sh. Creates ~/.claude/plugins/cleo symlink pointing to ~/.cleo/plugin/. Handle existing symlink removal. Add --skip-plugin flag option. Report plugin installation status. NEW: Also update to call injection setup for first-time installs (run cleo init automatically to set up both GLOBAL and PROJECT injections).

after.title: Update install.sh with plugin symlink support
after.description: REFRAMED: Add OPTIONAL --with-plugin flag to install.sh. NOT default behavior. Creates ~/.claude/plugins/cleo symlink only when explicitly requested. Most users will use injection system (auto-enabled). Plugin installation for advanced users who want Claude Code hooks.

before.title: Create plugin README.md documentation
before.description: Write plugin/README.md with: overview, prerequisites (CLEO CLI), installation, features (skills, commands, agents, hooks), configuration, troubleshooting. ~500 words. Include links to main CLEO docs.

after.title: Create plugin README.md documentation
after.description: REFRAMED: Write plugin README documenting HYBRID approach: (1) Injection system is PRIMARY (supports 16+ agents via registry), (2) Plugin is OPTIONAL for Claude Code hooks. Document: what plugin provides (SessionStart hook), what injection provides (multi-agent support, skills, protocols). Include decision tree for when to use plugin vs injection-only.

before.title: Create hook script unit tests
before.description: Write BATS tests for hook scripts. Test session-start.sh with mock CLAUDE_PROJECT_DIR. Test check-focus.sh with various user prompts. Test JSON output format. Test error handling for missing ct command.

after.title: Create hook script unit tests
after.description: REFRAMED: Write BATS tests for SessionStart hook only. Test: session-start.sh with mock CLAUDE_PROJECT_DIR, CLEO_SESSION binding, error handling for missing cleo CLI. Minimal test scope matching T1084 minimal hook scope.

before.title: Integration testing in Claude Code
before.description: Manual integration testing checklist: Plugin loads in /plugins. Skill triggers on task-related phrases. Commands appear in /help and execute. Agents trigger on matching scenarios. Hooks fire on events. Test with claude --debug. NEW: Validate GLOBAL injection present in ~/.claude/CLAUDE.md and PROJECT injection present in project CLAUDE.md. Test skill progressive disclosure loads correctly.

after.title: Integration testing in Claude Code
after.description: REFRAMED: Integration testing for HYBRID system. Two test matrices: (1) INJECTION: Test auto-discovery, CLAUDE.md/AGENTS.md/GEMINI.md injection, multi-agent registry, skill invocation. (2) PLUGIN (optional): Test hooks.json loading, SessionStart fires, session binding works. Both should work independently and together.

before.title: Update main CLEO documentation for plugin
before.description: Update README.md installation section to mention plugin and injection system. Update CONTRIBUTING.md with plugin development info and injection template maintenance. Add plugin section to docs/. Cross-reference plugin README. Update CHANGELOG.md for plugin release. NEW: Document three-tier architecture for contributors: CLEO-INJECTION.md (global), AGENT-INJECTION.md (project), cleo-task-management skill (progressive disclosure).

after.title: Update main CLEO documentation for plugin
after.description: Update main CLEO documentation for HYBRID architecture: (1) README.md - document injection as primary, plugin as optional, (2) Installation section - show injection auto-setup, optional --with-plugin, (3) Multi-agent support section - document registry, supported agents, (4) Plugin section - what it adds (Claude Code hooks), when to use. Cross-link to hybrid README.

before.title: Execute: Archive stale claudedocs (post-audit)
before.description:
Execute archive operation for AUDIT-approved files:

Prerequisites:
- T2532 audit complete
- T2530 gap-check command available
- HITL approval of archive list

Steps:
1. Run cleo docs gap-check --all-review
2. Present gap report to HITL
3. For files with gaps: flag for content extraction
4. For files without gaps: archive approved

Archive process:
- Move to claudedocs/archive/ with dated subdirectory
- Update frontmatter status to 'archived'
- Log archive operation to cleo log
- Preserve file for recovery if needed

Target: Archive 80%+ of 543 files (~435 files)

before.title: EPIC: CLEO Changesets - Dynamic Changelog from Release Tasks
before.description: CRITICAL: Changelog must be dynamically generated from release task metadata. GAPS: 1) cleo release ship doesn't auto-generate changelog from tasks. 2) Task descriptions/labels not used for changelog entries. 3) Commits not grouped by release version. 4) Changelog not attached to release entry. 5) No provenance tracking in changelog. MUST: Use tasks.labels for changelog categories (feat/fix/docs). Generate from task.title + task.description. Attach to release.changelog field. Track which agent generated. Follow RCSD-IVTR with circular validation.

before.title: ENHANCEMENT: Consolidate fix/repair terminology and functionality into unified pattern
before.description:
## Problem Statement
The codebase currently uses inconsistent terminology and patterns for auto-fixing/repairing data:
1. `validate --fix` - Fixes checksum, focus mismatch, multiple active tasks
2. `migrate repair` - Fixes phase structure, _meta fields, focus fields
3. `init --update-claude-md` - Updates CLAUDE.md injection

This creates confusion about:
- When to use which command
- What each command actually fixes
- Flag conventions (--fix vs repair subcommand)

## Current State Analysis

### `validate --fix` capabilities:
- Updates checksum to match tasks array
- Fixes focus.currentTask to match active task
- Keeps only first active task (deactivates others)
- Updates CLAUDE.md injection if outdated

### `migrate repair` capabilities:
- Ensures canonical 5-phase structure
- Adds missing phases, removes obsolete phases
- Fixes phase ordering
- Ensures _meta has all required fields
- Ensures focus has all required fields
- Preserves existing status/timestamps

### Flag Convention Inconsistencies:
- Some commands use `--flag` (double dash): --fix, --dry-run, --auto
- Some commands use subcommands: repair, status, run
- No consistent pattern across CLI

## Proposed Solution

### Option A: Unified `--fix` flag
Add `--fix` flag to all relevant commands:
- `validate --fix` (existing)
- `migrate --fix` (instead of `migrate repair`)
- `init --fix` (fix project issues)

### Option B: Standalone `repair` command
Create `claude-todo repair` as top-level command:
- `repair --dry-run` - Preview all repairs
- `repair --auto` - Apply all repairs
- `repair phases` - Fix phases only
- `repair schema` - Fix schema compliance
- `repair checksum` - Fix checksums

### Option C: Hybrid (Recommended)
Keep `validate --fix` for validation-related fixes
Create `claude-todo repair` for structural repairs
Ensure both produce consistent output format

## Implementation Tasks (if approved)
1. Create lib/repair.sh with reusable repair interface
2. Refactor migrate repair to use lib/repair.sh
3. Add repair logic for other scenarios
4. Ensure consistent flag naming across CLI
5. Update documentation
6. Add integration tests for repair scenarios

## Decision Needed
- Which option to implement (A, B, or C)?
- Should --fix and repair both exist or consolidate?
- What is the "escape hatch" for users when things break?

before.title: Standardize JSON results field across all commands
before.description: CRITICAL LLM-AGENT-FIRST: Agents using CLEO will NEVER see the spec - CLEO must be self-documenting through its JSON output. Currently commands use different field names: list=.tasks, find=.matches, blockers=.blockedTasks, deps=.dependencies. FIX OPTIONS: (A) Standardize all to .tasks with command-specific metadata, OR (B) Add _meta.resultsField to every response telling agents which field contains results. Option B is non-breaking. Implementation in output functions, NOT documentation.

details.title: Research: Autonomous Self-Improvement Ticket Logging System

after.title: Research: Autonomous Self-Improvement Ticket Logging System

before.title: Research: Autonomous Self-Improvement Ticket Logging System
before.description:
Research and design automated system for agents to log self-improvement tickets when witnessing issues during operation.

PROBLEM:
- Agents discover bugs/issues during work but may not log them
- No enforced mechanism to capture witnessed issues
- Cross-provider CLI agents (Claude Code, Codex, Gemini CLI, Kimi, etc.) need unified approach

RESEARCH AREAS:
1. **Detection Patterns**: What types of issues should trigger auto-logging?
   - CLI output failures (silent errors, swallowed output)
   - Session state inconsistencies
   - Protocol violations
   - Unexpected behavior patterns

2. **Logging Mechanism**: How to enforce ticket creation?
   - Hook-based (PostToolUse hooks detect anomalies)
   - Manifest-based (agents MUST log issues to manifest)
   - Compliance check (validate issues were logged)

3. **Cross-Provider Compatibility**: Design for multi-agent ecosystem
   - Claude Code hooks
   - Codex/OpenAI function calling patterns
   - Gemini CLI integration
   - Kimi and other emerging agents
   - Common protocol/schema for issue logging

4. **Autonomy vs Control**: Balance between auto-logging and noise
   - Severity thresholds for auto-create
   - Dedup mechanism (don't create duplicate tickets)
   - Human review queue vs direct creation

DESIRED OUTPUT:
- Design doc for autonomous issue logging
- Proposed schema for cross-provider compatibility
- Hook/trigger implementation strategy
- Integration points with CLEO task system

PROVENANCE: Discovered need during T2802 orchestrator work - multiple CLI issues went unlogged until manually noticed

after.title: Research: Autonomous Self-Improvement Ticket Logging System

Research and design automated system for agents to log self-improvement tickets when witnessing issues during operation.

PROBLEM:
- Agents discover bugs/issues during work but may not log them
- No enforced mechanism to capture witnessed issues
- Cross-provider CLI agents (Claude Code, Codex, Gemini CLI, Kimi, etc.) need unified approach

RESEARCH AREAS:
1. **Detection Patterns**: What types of issues should trigger auto-logging?

   - Session state inconsistencies
   - Protocol violations

   - Hook-based (PostToolUse hooks detect anomalies)
   - Manifest-based (agents MUST log issues to manifest)

   - Claude Code hooks

before.title: Deprecate dev/release-version.sh - merge into cleo release ship
before.description:
dev/release-version.sh (432 lines) duplicates functionality that should be in scripts/release.sh. CLEO must dogfood itself.

## Current Duplication
| Feature | dev/release-version.sh | scripts/release.sh |
|---------|----------------------|-------------------|
| Version bumping |  (calls bump-version.sh) |  |
| Git commit/tag |  |  |
| Git push |  |  |
| Changelog gen |  (Mintlify only) |  (task-based) |
| Validation gates |  |  |
| Dry-run mode |  |  |

## Required Changes
1. Move all dev/release-version.sh logic into `cleo release ship`
2. `cleo release ship` should:
   - Run validation gates
   - Auto-generate changelog from commits
   - Bump version (patch/minor/major)
   - Update CHANGELOG.md
   - Commit and tag
   - Push (with --push flag)
3. Mark dev/release-version.sh as deprecated
4. Add deprecation warning if directly called
5. Eventually remove (after transition period)

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] `cleo release ship v0.78.0 --push` does everything
- [ ] dev/release-version.sh shows deprecation warning
- [ ] No functionality loss
- [ ] Works for ANY project using CLEO (not just CLEO itself)

before.title: EPIC: Release System v2 - Project-Agnostic CI/CD Integration
before.description:
## Problem

Current release system is CLEO-specific: hardcoded tarballs, single CI/CD workflow, no project configuration. Not usable for other project types (npm, Python, Go, etc.).

## Goals

1. **Project-Agnostic Config**: Artifact types, package ecosystems, CI/CD templates in .cleo/config.json
2. **RCSD-IVTR Integration**: Full provenance from Task  Changelog  Release  Artifact
3. **Configurable CI/CD**: Templates for GitHub Actions, GitLab CI, CircleCI
4. **Release Provenance**: Task traceability, breaking change detection, version impact analysis

## Success Criteria

- Release config in .cleo/config.json (not hardcoded)
- CI/CD template generation for 3+ platforms
- Artifact type configuration (tarball, npm, wheel, binary)
- RCSD-IVTR gates enforced in release workflow
- Provenance chain: Task  Changelog  Release

## Scope

lib/release.sh, scripts/release.sh, schemas/config.schema.json, templates/, protocols/release.md

before.title: Make documentation platform configurable (Mintlify optional)
before.description:
Currently Mintlify is hardcoded. Projects should choose their doc platform.

## Current Hardcoding
```bash
# generate-changelog.sh line 10
CHANGELOG_DST="$PROJECT_ROOT/docs/changelog/overview.mdx"
```

## Proposed Config Schema
```json
{
  "release": {
    "changelog": {
      "enabled": true,
      "format": "keep-a-changelog",
      "autoGenerate": true,
      "source": "CHANGELOG.md",
      "outputs": [
        {
          "platform": "mintlify",
          "enabled": true,
          "path": "docs/changelog/overview.mdx",
          "template": "mintlify-changelog"
        },
        {
          "platform": "docusaurus",
          "enabled": false,
          "path": "docs/changelog.md"
        },
        {
          "platform": "github",
          "enabled": true,
          "useReleaseNotes": true
        }
      ]
    }
  }
}
```

## Supported Platforms
1. **mintlify** - MDX with accordions (current)
2. **docusaurus** - Standard markdown
3. **github** - GitHub release notes
4. **gitbook** - GitBook format
5. **plain** - Keep-a-Changelog only (no conversion)
6. **custom** - User-provided template

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Config schema supports multiple output platforms
- [ ] Each platform can be enabled/disabled independently
- [ ] Projects without Mintlify work correctly
- [ ] Default preserves current behavior (Mintlify enabled)
- [ ] `cleo init --detect` detects doc platform from existing files

before.title: Bug: Pre-commit hook checks working dir not staged files
before.description:
Drift detection pre-commit hook checks working directory instead of staged files.

## Current Behavior
```bash
# Fix is staged but hook still fails
git diff --cached | grep backfill  # Shows fix IS staged
git commit  # FAILS - hook checks working dir
```

## Expected Behavior
Hook should check staged content using:
```bash
git show :docs/commands/COMMANDS-INDEX.json
```

## Fix Location
.git/hooks/pre-commit or dev/skills/ct-docs-sync/scripts/detect-drift.sh

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Hook uses git show for staged files
- [ ] Valid commits with staged fixes pass

## Acceptance Criteria

before.title: Bug: Session start fails when epic has no pending tasks
before.description:
Can't start session with --auto-focus when all epic tasks are done.

## Current Behavior
```
cleo session start --scope epic:T2666 --auto-focus
Error: E_SCOPE_EMPTY - No pending tasks in scope for auto-focus
```

## Expected Behavior
Should allow session start even with no pending tasks, or provide better workflow.

## Options
1. Allow session without focus when all done
2. Auto-create 'followup' task for notes/commits
3. Allow --no-focus flag

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Can start session on completed epic for notes/commit
- [ ] Clear workflow for post-completion work

before.title: Investigate: Project registry not persisting after upgrade
before.description: After deploying v0.50.3 fixes, ~/.cleo/projects-registry.json is missing again despite appearing to be created during upgrade. Symptoms: (1) Registry file existed briefly at 08:12, (2) Now missing after subsequent operations, (3) upgrade.sh update_project_registration() may have logic issues. Need deep investigation of: when registry is created vs deleted, race conditions, error paths that silently fail, whether backup/restore operations affect registry. This is a regression from the T1520 fix.

after.title: Investigate: Project registry not persisting after upgrade
after.description: After deploying v0.50.3 fixes, ~/.cleo/projects-registry.json is missing again despite appearing to be created during upgrade. Symptoms: (1) Registry file existed briefly at 08:12, (2) Now missing after subsequent operations, (3) upgrade.sh update_project_registration() may have logic issues. Need deep investigation of: when registry is created vs deleted, race conditions, error paths that silently fail, whether backup/restore operations affect registry. This is a regression from the T1520 fix.

before.title: EPIC: CLEO v2.0 TypeScript Implementation
before.description:
Implementation of CLEO v2.0 based on validated architecture decisions (ADR approved 2026-01-23).

Key Changes:
1. TypeScript port with Commander.js + esbuild (D1, D5)
2. Four-gate manifest validation architecture (D3)
3. DEBT-LEDGER.jsonl for TODO/FIXME tracking (D4)
4. Dependency algorithm optimization O(n^2) to O(n) (D2)
5. Multi-agent consensus protocol with 2/3 majority (D6)

Phases:
- Phase 1: Foundation (project setup, core modules, basic commands)
- Phase 2: Core Commands (task lifecycle, focus, session, hierarchy)
- Phase 3: Feature Parity (all 50+ commands, optimization)
- Phase 4: Polish (performance, docs, migration, parallel release)

Success Criteria:
- 100% exit code parity (49 codes)
- <50ms startup time
- <500KB bundle size
- 80%+ test coverage
- All BATS integration tests pass

Reference: claudedocs/CLEO-V2-ARCHITECTURE-DECISIONS.md

before.title: Research: Folder Structure & Memory-Trees Agent Architecture
before.description:
Multi-phase research initiative investigating two interconnected topics:

1. **Codebase Folder Structure Analysis**: Evaluate current flat folder organization, identify benefits/drawbacks, and explore reorganization possibilities.

2. **Memory-Trees Subagent Architecture**: Novel concept for enhancing agent context traversal:
   - Memory trees as folder-anchored context zones
   - 4-5 tier pyramid with subagents passing information
   - Cross-cutting capability between memory trees (like an internal API)
   - More precise context, less contextual rot
   - Subagents guiding information from one subfolder to another

**Scope**: Investigation and research ONLY - no changes to codebase.

**Deliverables**:
- Current folder structure analysis report
- Memory-trees architecture concept document
- Consensus on potential benefits/risks
- Recommendations for CLEO enhancement (if warranted)

before.title: Phase 1 testing: manifest hierarchy unit and integration tests
before.description: Write comprehensive tests for the manifest hierarchy extension. Unit tests (BATS): (1) Test field writers with valid parentId/path/depth. (2) Test tree invariant violations (missing parent, cycles, depth exceeded). (3) Test backward compatibility (entries without hierarchy fields). (4) Test childCount increment/decrement. (5) Test path computation from parentId chain. Integration tests: (6) Test backfill script on fixture data. (7) Test manifest append with hierarchy in full workflow. (8) Performance benchmark: validation overhead with 1K entries. All tests in tests/unit/manifest-hierarchy.bats and tests/integration/manifest-hierarchy.bats.

before.title: Phase 2 performance benchmarks and go/no-go validation
before.description: Run performance benchmarks comparing tree-aware queries vs flat manifest linear search. Benchmarks: (1) Subtree query at 400 entries (current size). (2) Subtree query at 1K entries (synthetic data). (3) Subtree query at 10K entries (synthetic data). (4) Tree visualization render time at each scale. (5) Aggregate computation time. (6) Memory usage comparison. Go/no-go criteria from T2748: subtree queries must be 10x faster than linear at 1K entries, tree visualization must render in less than 1s. Document results and recommendation for Phase 3-4 (navigator/synthesizer tiers). If criteria not met, document findings and halt memory-trees expansion.
